utterances: The Little Rock school district then came under federal court supervision and remained there until yesterday.
That's when a U.S.
District Court judge accepted a promise by the Little Rock School Board to track the progress of black students without federal oversight.
This day seemed a long way off in 1957, when one of Central High's first black students spoke to a television reporter.
(Soundbite of broadcast)
I'm Minnijean Brown.
I'm thankful for the many people who have stood by us and (unintelligible)...
Minnijean Brown-Trickey joins us now on the line from Little Rock.
Welcome to the program.
And when I asked you both last Friday about the potential consequences of that spill in the gulf, frankly, I didn't think we'd still be following it a week later.
It's bigger than we thought.
There's some federal malfeasance alleged.
You just heard what the president said.
David, first, is it a game changer on energy policy?
I don't think so.
I was pessimistic last week, and I'm even more pessimistic this week.
I think what's happened in the past week is we - what's gone from a technical spill now seems like a systemic spill, with problems in the government, problems in the companies.
So it seems like a wider thing.
The question is, is this energy bill, which John Kerry and Joe Lieberman actually - sort of have re-announced this week, is it going anywhere?
And I still think this spill, paradoxically, makes it much harder for it to go anywhere because legitimately, there's going to be a moratorium on offshore oil exploration.
And if you knock that off, you've really knocked out the coalition you need to pass this thing.
E.J., what do you think about the spill and politics?
Well, I think it is a partial game-changer in politics.
The president really went on the offensive today.
FDR had his famous trilogy of Republican congressmen Martin, Barton and Fish.
And you have a nice corporate trinity here: BP, Transocean and Halliburton.
And he also went after the management of the Minerals Management Service and implicitly attacked the way it was run under President Bush.
You don't have to be a liberal to believe the Bush-Cheney administration had a cozy relationship with oil companies.
You just had to be sentient.
And so I think this is an argument that's going to have some legs to it.
And you know, when you look at these elections this year, Democrats have to shift some of the public's anger away from government and toward the corporate sector.
I think they're doing that on Wall Street reform, as they've wisely renamed financial reform, and I think they're now doing it with the oil spill.
Well, what the American people see is the marriage between corporate and governmental power, and that's what we're upset about.
It's not really a partisan issue that the agency was captured by the oil industry.
Every agency is captured by oil industries.
It happened under Obama.
It happened under Bush.
It's become...
No, but this Obama's I disagree with that.
I mean, I think that the Bush administration's relationship with the oil companies, the secret meetings Cheney had when they wrote their energy bills.
I mean, this is a very deep relationship on a good part of the Republican side.
And I think there is a real potential to turn this into a partisan issue.
David?
Well, I guess I think if you look at the anger that's out there, just speaking politically, the anger is against the axis of Wall Street and Washington, the axis of corporations in Washington.
Even the energy bill - which I support - believe me, there's plenty of payoffs to people, the industries you need to get this thing passed.
So I think just speaking politically, what the American people are upset about, it's not corporations or government, it's both - in the way they're intermingled.
Second item: The other big political development this week was President Obama's nomination of Elena Kagan to succeed Justice John Paul Stevens on the Supreme Court.
You both wrote columns about her, obviously.
E.J., you wrote that you know her, you like her, you expect that in her confirmation hearings, she'll give the senators no more and no less than John Roberts did - which isn't much.
Why?
Well, because there is no incentive in this system to give any more or less.
And if things are asked of Kagan that were not asked of John Roberts, it's clearly a double standard.
What strikes me - and David sort of wrote a column about Kagan in an earlier column about Roberts - and what strikes me is how similar they are.
They only lack in common the fact that he was a circuit court judge, and she wasn't.
She was named in her - the Republicans held up her nomination back then; it just never got anywhere.
But as someone who is well-liked, widely known by establishment lawyers on both sides, they are very similar people.
And so I think she's going to sail through.
A good thing happened to her this week.
Scott Brown, Republican of Massachusetts, came out and defended her on the issue of allowing military recruiters on the Harvard Law School campus.
She allowed them on but indirectly, not formally, and she signed a brief because of her opposition to Don't Ask Don't Tell.
Scott Brown stood up for her respect for the military - which, by the way, is a view I heard her express privately.
So I think she's had a good week so far.

David, you described her as someone whom we don't know that much about intellectually, what she actually believes in, because you discovered someone who has tactically kept herself undisclosed all this time.
Yeah.
What I did was, I went back and I read all of the or at least as many of the public speeches and statements that I could get my hands on.
And in person, everybody I know - I don't know her, but everybody I know who knows her, right and left, admires her, likes her, said she did a very good job as Harvard Law School dean.
But what struck me about these speeches - going back a long time - was her reticence about expressing an opinion on anything.
In her early 20s, she really was quite opinionated, and stuff has come out about Liz Holtzman and other candidates she worked for.
She was quite passionate.
Then suddenly something everything clammed up.
And so when you read the speeches, they're designed not to give you an opinion, but to not commit herself to anything in public.
And that sort of caution - I understand the incentives which drive a potential Supreme Court justice to that sort of caution, but I still feel compelled to protest against it.
It's sort of like the opposite of those partisan review writers who chose, in their terms, to be contentious intellectuals.
She chose to be an uncontentious intellectual.
Yeah, and it's paid off.
I mean, she's had a very good career, very productive career, and I assume she'll get approved to the Supreme Court.
I just, you know - and there are so many pressures in life, which all really serious legal minds face, to be very reticent.
And a lot of people do not succumb to that.
They just let it rip because they feel they want to contribute to the world of ideas.
She was reticent, and I'm sort of a little disturbed by that.
(Soundbite of ""Howl's Moving Castle"")
But so was John Roberts.
And you know, it's funny, Kagan wrote a very - kind of puckish piece about the whole confirmation process years ago and referred to its how vacuous it could be.
And I just can't resist paraphrasing Barry Goldwater and say, in these circumstances of - acuity in the quest for confirmation is no vice.
(Soundbite of laughter)
E.J.
Dionne and David Brooks, thanks to both of you.
Thank you.
Once President Obama signs the health-care bill into law, it won't be long before some of its provisions take effect.
Let's start with what supporters call the early deliverables.
Within 90 days, people who lack health insurance because of pre-existing conditions will qualify for coverage in a high-risk pool.
Within six months, insurance companies will be barred from denying coverage to children with pre-existing conditions.
They will also be barred from imposing lifetime caps on coverage, and from dropping people from their health plans once they get sick.
Turning now to provisions that will help pay for this bill, next year, 2011, drug makers will begin paying fees on the sale of brand-name drugs to the government.
And in 2013, new Medicare taxes will be introduced.
They'll affect the investment income of individuals earning more than $200,000 a year, and couples earning more than $250,000 a year.
In the year 2014, most people will be required to have health insurance.
Medicaid will also expand to cover more Americans.
Insurers will no longer be able to deny coverage to anyone with pre-existing conditions.
And health-care exchanges will begin, providing a place to shop for health insurance to people who don't get coverage through work.
On the far end of the timeline, 2018 is the year when the so-called Cadillac insurance plans come under a 40 percent excise tax.
And by 2019, if all goes according to plan, the bill's final goal will be reached: health-care coverage for 32 million uninsured Americans.
As NPR's Gwen Thompkins reports from the Ethiopian capital, Addis Ababa.
(SOUNDBITE OF CAR ENGINE)
For most people in Addis Ababa, the war in Somalia seems far removed from daily life.
Ethiopia's military support of the Transitional Government in Somalia has landed this country in a holy war with Somalia's Islamists, the Islamic Courts Union.
What's more, the Islamic Courts have threatened to attack Addis Ababa itself.
But people here seem more concerned with other matters.
On this weekday, many of the children went to school; many of their parents went to work.
The vendors got to vending, the beggars got to begging, and even the birds revved up for their morning sing-along.
(SOUNDBITE OF BIRDS CHIRPING)
But somewhere in the air was the faint sound of crowing.
Amare Aregawi is the editor-in-chief and owner of The Reporter, one of the daily newspapers here.
He's a true believer in Ethiopia's war with the Islamic Courts Union.
He says the Islamic Courts have been commandeered by foreign extremists who threaten the entire region.
There is an international extremist force who wants to settle in the Horn of Africa and East Africa, and the force will expand to Africa.
That force has to be dismantled, weakened.
Over the weekend, the Islamic Courts announced plans for a guerilla war against Ethiopia.
But Aregawi is betting all the way on the superiority of Ethiopia's military, a force forged in part in a long-fought rebellion that overthrew former dictator Mengistu Haile Mariam.
We shouldn't forget the backbone of the Ethiopian military.
This is a force that has toppled the previous government through guerilla warfare.
They have been themselves 17 years in the bush with guerilla warfaring - the very force itself that is in Somalia now.
That's the kind of talk that makes Somali national Mogadin Orasuge(ph) think about buying a ticket home.
Orasuge has a wife and six children in Mogadishu.
He also lives in a neighborhood in Addis that the people here call Mogadishu.
He couldn't be happier with the way the war is going.
Yes, yes, yes, yes, we are very glad that.
We are very glad, very glad, because after this time I can go to my country, to my home.
If the government is there in Mogadishu, I will go to my home.
But there are some people in Addis who wanted to avoid war in Somalia altogether.
Well, we're not convinced that the situation did warrant a declaration of war.
That's Beyene Petros.
He is one of the few vocal members of Ethiopia's political opposition.
In parliament, his party opposed a bill to move Ethiopia closer to war with the Islamic Courts.
Petros says his country should be spending more of its energies on eradicating poverty at home, feeding the hungry and in resolving its ongoing border dispute with Eritrea.
But he says that many political activists here do not feel free to talk publicly.
That's because many of Ethiopia's political dissenters have been jailed since elections last year.
The (unintelligible).

You see, the thing is not that it is in the policy of the government or a (unintelligible) or the law of the land of not (unintelligible) provides protection, but one of our parliamentarians threatened on the street, you know, who voted with us.
And Issac Eshid(ph), a Muslim student at Addis Ababa University, says that many young people especially are against the war.
The Ethiopian Christians, the Ethiopian Muslims, especially the youngsters, are really against this war.
Nobody wants a war.
